title: Bi-Weekly Movies, TV Shows, Documentaries & Podcasts Discussion Thread
selftext:
So, what is r/India watching of late?

Watched any premieres yesterday? Loved any movie that you saw recently and are dying to discuss it? Discovered any new series lately? Well, this is your space. Go crazy!

This is not just limited to Hollywood/Bollywood, nor to any particular language.

Feel free to share short films, or podcasts of your choice, too, and ask for recommendations for what to watch!

**Movies and Shows Thread is posted every two weeks on Saturday mornings |** [**Old Threads**](https://reddit.com/r/india/search?q=Movies+thread+discussion+&restrict_sr=on&sort=new&t=all)

https://preview.redd.it/e3cqi5nuw8n61.png?width=1487&format=png&auto=webp&s=c6623226acf7856bb5a61313af7bec382c8525f1
comments:
I was very happy to watch Asteroid City last Sunday. As a big Wes Anderson fan it was cool finally seeing one of his films on the big screen, even if I didn't love it as much as the rest. 

Did any of you get to see it, and if so thoughts?

Scam 2003 (SonyLiv). This Hansal Mehta show is almost as good as the first one. It might get some time getting used to - Abdul Karim Telgi doesn't *look* like the charming hero as Harshad Mehta did. But once you ease up to the character, you realise tha the show offer the same thrill, vanity and captivating experience. 

Did you guys enjoy it?

One piece live action. Its not half bad. Its even half good. And I hate live action anime for the record. Its not db evolution at all . This is good enough to get cancelled by netflix and that makes me sad

I watched Suzhal last week and it was great!  Dahaad was also amazing.  Both are on Prime in the US.  Does anyone have a recommendation on more shows like Suzhal?  I especially love small town or village life and the religious festival was a real bonus.  Kantara is another example of a great movie with religious elements and village life.

This will be pretty vague, but about 3 years ago I saw a cop miniseries that was just bonkers.  It was on Prime or Netflix.  It had supernatural/religious elements and frankly the plot was hard for a westerner to follow.  It was pretty mind-blowing.  One thing that stuck with me is that one detective had chairs and tables but another detective lived on the floor in his place.  Same income but 2 totally different ways of living.  Last year they released season 2.   I can't remember the name.  Does this sound familiar to anyone?
